0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-asia-idUSKCN12A0KJ	Asia investors
column2: traders bet on Clinton win after bruising election debate	"

column1: By Swati Pandey and Nichola Saminather
| SYDNEY/SINGAPORE

SYDNEY/SINGAPORE Investors and traders in Asia indicated on Monday they are mostly increasing their bets on Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton winning the U.S. presidential race after the second of three debates with Republican party nominee Donald Trump. Some
column2: though remain cautious
column3: saying there was still a chance of a surprise Trump win. They said many in the markets were wary after being burned by the shock ""Brexit"" vote in June.MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan edged up around 0.1 percent by mid-afternoon in Singapore on Monday
column4: while Wall Street index futures were little changed after Clinton exchanged barbs with Republican party nominee Donald Trump in the televised event
column5: which was shown live across trading rooms during Asia's morning. The 90-minute debate quickly turned into an acrimonious discussion of a 2005 video that emerged on Friday in which Trump was heard using vulgar language and talking about groping women.  The controversy has caused some senior Republicans to withdraw their support for him. ""For those that think that Trump has a very
column6: very low chance of winning the U.S. elections it might be a good time to go long on global equities
column7: said Itay Tuchman
column8: Citi's head of markets for Australia and New Zealand.Markets could be prematurely pricing in a Clinton victory
column9: as they did during the ""Brexit"" vote in June
column10: when the United Kingdom voted unexpectedly to leave the European Union
column12: research analyst for Aberdeen Asset Management in Singapore.""We need to remember that Brexit only became a key focus one week before the vote. The market had priced in near zero probability of it happening but it did."" According to a CNN online poll
column13: Clinton won the debate by  57 percent to 34 percent.

column1: But Josh Crabb
column2: head of Asian equities at Old Mutual Global Investors in Hong Kong
column3: said he is wary of such polls - especially after Brexit. ""The way that mainstream media
column4: and a lot of commentators
column5: interpret the outcome of the debate may be different to what the voting public in general takes away
column6: Crabb said. ""That is a concern because often
column7: a lot of these polls have not been quite as accurate as people are expecting.""Mathan Somasundarum
column8: a strategist at stock brokerage Baillieu Holst in Sydney
column9: said a Clinton victory would reduce the risk of the United States adopting a strong trade protectionist policy. Trump has been highly critical of the NAFTA trade deal with Mexico and Canada as well as the Trans-Pacific Partnership
column10: which has yet to be ratified by the U.S. Congress. He has promised to build a border wall and make Mexico pay for it.""I would expect the U.S. dollar to weaken and you would expect then there is some pressure coming off emerging markets
column12: which (are a) proxy for emerging markets
column14: commodities and the Aussie dollar should do better.""While the markets had already begun to price in a Clinton victory even before the Republican party's crisis over Trump's 2005 remarks
column15: some are beginning to game out what would happen if the Democrats won both houses of Congress

column1: The possibility of the Democrats controlling Congress and the White House is a concern to some in the markets as they see it leading to more regulation of businesses and higher taxes.""Over time
column2: people will start thinking
column3: is this going to mean a big difference in the way taxation works? Is it going to mean more government involvement?
column4: said Crabb at Old Mutual Global in Hong Kong. ""But the immediate reaction will be a relief rally.""Angus Gluskie
column5: managing director of White Funds Management in Sydney
column6: said while markets usually view one party dominating the government as a risk
column7: it could be different this time.""Investors have been disappointed by the political stalemate over recent years
column8: which has prevented meaningful and well-needed changes being pursued

column1: Steven Friedman
column2: senior investment strategist at BNP Paris bas Investment Partners in New York
column3: said he saw little in the debate that represented a game-changer for either candidate. ""This obviously plays to Clinton's advantage
column4: given her lead in the polls
column5: he said.Strategists in a recent Reuters equity poll mostly viewed an election victory on Nov. 8 by Clinton as more positive for the stock market through the end of the year
column6: largely because her positions - unlike her opponent's - are well-known. Chris Brankin
column7: chief executive at stock brokerage TD Ameritrade Asia
column8: said he thought Trump was much better prepared for the town hall debate in St. Louis than he was for the first debate
column9: and that could give markets some pause. ""I have always said markets 'know what they get' with Hillary
column10: as she as always been seen as pro-Wall Street and Trump is a bit of an unknown for investors.  ""After tonight's debate I still think there are a lot of questions as who will be elected into office next month and markets are probably going to remain range-bound till after the U.S. elections."" (Writing by Bill Tarrant.; Editing by Martin Howell.)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-storm-matthew-haiti-idUSKCN12A02W	Hurricane Matthew toll in Haiti rises to 1
column3: dead buried in mass graves	"

column1: By Joseph Guyler Delva
| PORT-AU-PRINCE
PORT-AU-PRINCE Haiti started burying some of its dead in mass graves in the wake of Hurricane Matthew
column2: a government official said on Sunday
column3: as cholera spread in the devastated southwest and the death toll from the storm rose to 1
column4: 000 people.The powerful hurricane
column5: the fiercest Caribbean storm in nearly a decade
column6: slammed into Haiti on Tuesday with 145 mile-per-hour (233 kph) winds and torrential rains that left 1.4 million people in need of humanitarian assistance
column7: the U.N. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said.A Reuters tally of numbers from local officials showed that 1
column8: 000 people were killed by the storm in Haiti
column9: which has a population of about 10 million and is the poorest country in the Americas.The official death toll from the central civil protection agency is 336
column10: a slower count because officials must visit each village to confirm the numbers.

column1: Authorities had to start burying the dead in mass graves in Jeremie because the bodies were starting to decompose
column2: said Kedner Frenel
column3: the most senior central government official in the Grand'Anse region on Haiti's western peninsula. Frenel said 522 people were killed in Grand'Anse alone. A tally of deaths reported by mayors from 15 of 18 municipalities in Sud Department on the south side of the peninsula showed 386 people there. In the rest of the country
column4: 92 people were killed
column5: the same tally showed.

column1: Frenel said there was great concern about cholera spreading
column2: and that authorities were focused on getting water
column3: food and medication to the thousands of people living in shelters.Cholera causes severe diarrhea and can kill within hours if untreated. It is spread through contaminated water and has a short incubation period
column4: which leads to rapid outbreaks.

column1: Government teams fanned out across the hard-hit southwestern tip of the country over the weekend to repair treatment centers and reach the epicenter of one outbreak. (Reporting by Joseph Guyler Delva; Writing by Christine Murray; Editing by Diane Craft and Paul Tait)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-socialmedia-idUSKCN12A0EE	Trump's body language during debate raises social media eyebrows	"
By Amy Tennery
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump paced
column2: frowned and physically loomed at times over Democratic rival Hillary Clinton during Sunday night's town-hall debate
column3: prompting bewilderment and mockery from some on social media.The online reaction underscored the contentious tone of the encounter in St. Louis in which Trump and Clinton hurled insults at each other less than a month before the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election.Twitter users seized on Trump's body language
column4: with some remarking that he appeared to have ""stalked"" Clinton around the stage. The criticism came as the Republican faces a political storm after being caught on a leaked 2005 videotape making lewd and demeaning remarks about women.""#Trump's body language [was] bizarre
column5: wrote Twitter user Sheena (@texdakota). ""Pacing
column6: insulting
column7: standing right behind her.""

column1: Trump's body language freaked me out
column2: wrote Charlotte (@charlotteirene8). ""I get very uncomfortable when men stand behind me
column3: especially like that.""A spokeswoman for Trump did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

column1: Clinton's performance inspired online criticism as well. ""Clinton could have done better
column2: tweeted ryank (@ryantkelly). ""Didn't seem as hungry
column3: as able to get under his skin tonight.""Sentiment on Trump's performance was 66.9 percent negative
column4: according to an analysis by social intelligence firm Brandwatch of Twitter posts during the debate
column5: while Clinton's was 57.8 percent negative.

column1: The debate
column2: which featured questions from audience members
column3: was the most tweeted-about debate ever
column4: with more than 17 million tweets
column5: said Twitter spokesman Nick Pacilio.Trump's statement that he and running mate Mike Pence differed on their approach to military intervention in Syria was the most-talked-about moment of the night on the microblogging site. (Reporting by Amy Tennery; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-moments-idUSKCN12A0CX	Trump
column2: Clinton spend much of debate insulting each other	"

column1: By Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON There was a moment in Sunday's U.S. presidential debate when Democrat Hillary Clinton was trying to fend off an attack from Republican rival Donald Trump about her use of a private email server while she was secretary of state.""It's just awfully good that someone with the temperament of Donald Trump is not in charge of the law in our country
column2: Clinton said of her rival for the Nov. 8 election.""Because you'd be in jail
column3: Trump shot back
column4: drawing a mix of gasps and applause from the crowd that was defying instructions to remain silent.It was one of the most explosive moments of the debate in St. Louis
column5: and unprecedented for one presidential candidate to suggest on a debate stage that his opponent should be in jail.The debate was crammed with moments that could at best be described as petty and at worse vicious - as the candidates traded personal attacks and sarcastic one-liners.Trump frequently interrupted Clinton and sparred with the two debate moderators
column6: who in turn chastised the crowd for occasional outbursts.

column1: When moderator Anderson Cooper asked Clinton if Trump had the discipline to be a good leader
column2: Clinton responded with one word: ""No.""""I'm shocked to hear that
column3: Trump responded sarcastically.He called Clinton names
column4: including referring to her as ""the devil"" when discussing the support for her by U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders
column5: Clinton's rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.

column1: We have a divided nation
column2: because people like her - and believe me
column3: she has tremendous hate in her heart
column4: Trump said a few minutes later.

column1: Clinton in turn jabbed at Trump for his lewd remarks about women captured on a 2005 videotape released on Friday that has thrown his candidacy into crisis.""OK
column2: Donald
column3: I know you're into big diversion tonight
column4: anything to avoid talking about your campaign and the way it's exploding and the way Republicans are leaving you
column5: Clinton said.After 90 minutes of such harsh exchanges
column6: the mood changed suddenly when the final question came from an audience member who asked each candidate to describe one admirable quality about the other.

column1: I respect his children. His children are incredibly able and devoted
column2: and I think that says a lot about Donald
column3: Clinton said.Trump said of Clinton: ""She doesn't quit
column4: she doesn't give up
column5: I respect that.""At the close of the debate
column6: they shook hands
column7: something they had notably avoided doing when the night started.  (Reporting by Ginger Gibson; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN1290JZ	U.S. Republicans in crisis over Trump's vulgar video	"
By Richard Cowan and Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON/ST. LOUIS
WASHINGTON/ST. LOUIS The U.S. Republican Party on Sunday confronted its biggest crisis in more than 40 years when its presidential nominee
column2: Donald Trump
column3: faced a storm over sexually aggressive comments he made about women in a newly uncovered 2005 video.Only a month before the Nov. 8 election and on a day when Trump was due to debate Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column4: Trump took to social media to squelch any speculation that he would leave the race.""Tremendous support (except for some Republican leadership""). Thank you
column5: Trump wrote on Twitter.Then in a last-minute surprise in St. Louis
column6: host city for the town-hall debate
column7: Trump called journalists into a hotel room to witness a meeting he held with four women who revived accusations of past sexual misdeeds by Clinton's husband
column8: former President Bill Clinton.The party turmoil recalled past party crises
column9: including the Watergate scandal that led to Republican President Richard Nixon's resignation in 1974.A businessman-turned-politician previously best known to Americans as a reality TV show host
column12: faced his latest crisis when on Friday the 2005 video emerged in which he was heard talking on an open microphone about groping women and trying to seduce a married woman. The video was taped only months after Trump married his third wife
column15: into the biggest crisis of his 16-month-old campaign and deepened fissures between him and establishment Republicans. On Sunday
column16: he struck a defiant tone in the face of calls for him to abandon the race.A source close to the campaign of Trump's vice presidential running mate
column18: dismissed talk among some political analysts the Indiana governor might bolt the ticket in the uproar over Trump's comments.""Absolutely not
column19: the source told Reuters.At a Democratic campaign event in Chicago
column20: President Barack Obama weighed in on the controversy
column21: saying Trump had been degrading not only to women

column1: Obama said that ""tells you he is insecure.""""He pumps himself up by putting other people down
column2: Obama said.SUPPORT WOBBLING

column1: With Republican Party leaders in crisis mode and doubts emerging over Trump's ability to draw support from crucial undecided voters
column2: there were nonetheless some early signs many of his core supporters would remain loyal.A public opinion poll by POLITICO/Morning Consult
column3: taken just after news broke of the video
column4: found 39 percent of voters thought Trump should withdraw
column5: and 45 percent said he should stay. Of those who said Trump should leave
column6: only 12 percent identified themselves as Republicans.

column1: As of Sunday afternoon
column2: at least 160 of the United States' 332 sitting Republican governors
column3: senators and House of Representatives members had condemned Trump's remarks
column4: according to a Reuters review of official statements and local news coverage.At least 30 had called for him to withdraw from the race and three other officeholders said he should consider doing so. Eight of those said they were withdrawing their endorsement as well.Those facing a difficult re-election were more likely to speak out. All but six of the 40 Republican officeholders whose races are considered competitive had condemned Trump's comments on the video
column5: although only three members of that group called for him to drop out.Any attempt to replace Trump on the ballot would face huge legal and logistical hurdles. The Trump campaign was battling back
column6: circulating ""talking points"" to a core of high-profile Republicans who promote Trump in the news media. The points sought to undermine establishment Republicans who have abandoned Trump.

column1: They are more concerned with their political future than they are about the future of the country
column2: said a copy of the talking points
column3: described to Reuters by two sources close to the campaign.A real estate developer making his first run at public office
column4: Trump has made his battle against the establishment a central campaign theme.""Phones have been blowing up for the past 24 hours
column5: said a prominent Republican political operative in Washington
column6: referring to a heavy volume of calls among party officials and Republican members of Congress.   DOWN-BALLOT RACES

column1: The operative
column2: who did not want to be identified
column3: said Trump's troubles could steer campaign donations away from him and to Republican candidates for Congress and other down-ballot offices.The source said Trump could help himself most during the presidential debate - the second of three before the election - if he addressed the video and an Oct. 1 New York Times report that he took so substantial a tax deduction on a declared $916 million loss in 1995 that he could legally have avoided paying any federal income taxes for up to 18 years.Despite having recovered from a string of setbacks
column4: Trump had an uphill battle to win the White House. Before the video surfaced
column5: a Reuters/Ipsos poll had Clinton leading by 5 points on Friday. The question now is whether Trump's quest for the presidency has been dealt a lethal blow. (Reporting by Steve Holland in St. Louis and Richard Cowan in Washington; Additional reporting by Jeff Mason
column6: Ginger Gibson
column7: Alana Wise
column8: Susan Heavey
column11: Diane Bartz and Susan Heavey in Washington
column12: Emily Flitter and Grant Smith in New York and Ayesha Rascoe in Chicago; Editing by Howard Goller and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-pressure-idUSKCN1290AS	Pressure on Trump likely to be intense at second debate with Clinton	"
By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column2: facing eroding support from his party over lewd remarks about women
column3: goes into a second presidential debate with Democrat Hillary Clinton on Sunday needing to demonstrate he remains a credible candidate.The pressure on the 70-year-old Trump at the debate will be intense. Not only must he parry attacks from Clinton and explain why he is a better alternative. He must also show an apologetic side to stop more Republican supporters from giving up on him.Trump already had an uphill battle to win the White House in the Nov. 8 election before disclosure of a 2005 video in which he could be heard talking crudely about women.A Reuters-Ipsos poll had Clinton leading by five points on Friday
column4: before the video surfaced. Now
column5: the question is whether Trump's quest for the presidency is all but over.The fresh controversy adds an air of unpredictability over the 9 p.m. EDT debate at Washington University in St. Louis
column6: the second of three scheduled presidential debates as the long-running U.S. election contest enters its final weeks.It will be a town hall-style debate with undecided voters posing half the questions and the debate's two moderators posing the others.His vice presidential running mate
column7: Mike Pence
column8: said on Sunday that Trump needs to show contrition.

column1: We pray for his family and look forward to the opportunity to show what is in his heart when he goes before the nation tomorrow night
column2: Pence said in a statement.The crisis has put the Republican National Committee in a tight spot with less than a month to go until Election Day.Trump would have to resign the nomination to allow Republican leaders to choose a successor
column3: but the New York businessman is showing no signs of stepping down despite increasing calls from elected leaders for him to let Pence become the nominee.""The media and establishment want me out of the race so badly - I WILL NEVER DROP OUT OF THE RACE
column4: WILL NEVER LET MY SUPPORTERS DOWN!"" Trump tweeted on Sunday from Trump Tower in New York.

column1: At the first debate
column2: on Sept. 26
column3: Trump was repeatedly put on the defensive by Clinton. He never let her accusations go unanswered
column4: and as a result he missed opportunities to use his speaking time to draw attention to Clinton's perceived weaknesses.Republicans said Trump needed to perform more like Pence
column5: who was deemed the winner in his vice presidential debate against Democratic rival Tim Kaine last week.Republican strategist Ron Bonjean said there is plenty Trump could learn from Pence
column6: who stayed on offense at the vice-presidential debate
column7: did not bother to respond to Kaine's accusations
column8: and looked calm and unflappable.""It was a clear lesson in how you avoid falling into your opponent's traps
column9: Bonjean said. ""Don't talk about what the other side wants you to talk about
column10: focus on what you want to talk about.""

column1: Clinton has been hunkered down for days getting ready for what could be
column2: for her
column3: a knockout blow against Trump.Before the video surfaced
column4: Clinton campaign officials said they were expecting the Republican nominee to come to the debate more subdued than the first round.But they were also prepared in case Trump follows through with a threat to focus on Clinton's sometimes troubled marriage to former President Bill Clinton.Clinton
column5: who has already capitalized on Trump's treatment of women
column6: herself foreshadowed how she might respond to an attack from Trump on her marriage during a speech to a fundraiser in Washington on Wednesday.""I feel it's my responsibility not to defend myself against his attacks because
column7: really
column8: been there
column10: she said. ""I think it's my responsibility to defend everybody else against his attacks
column12: drawing cheers from the crowd.Clinton has her own issues to face. Wikileaks on Friday published an email from Clinton advisers appearing to contain excerpts of paid speeches to corporations
column13: in which Clinton voices support for open trade and borders and says how sometimes it is important to have a public and private position.

column1: (Reporting by Steve Holland in Washington and Jeff Mason in White Plains
column2: New York; Editing by Leslie Adler
column3: Bernard Orr)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-mexico-peso-idUSKCN1290XJ	Mexican peso surges ahead of U.S. presidential debate	"
MEXICO CITY Mexico's peso surged more than 1.8 percent against the dollar on Sunday ahead of the U.S. presidential debate
column2: after comments Donald Trump made about women in a video created a storm around his campaign.The currency moved after markets in Asia began Monday trading. At 3 p.m. CDT (2000 GMT)
column3: the peso had strengthened 1.89 percent to 18.955 per dollar.Republican nominee Donald Trump has vowed he would build a wall on the border with Mexico and renegotiate or scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement if he is elected.

column1: The United States is Mexico's main trading partner and Wall Street analysts say concern over any potential trade restrictions have hurt the peso.
(Reporting by Mexico City Newsroom; Editing by Bill Trott)"
7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-republican-scenarios-idUSKCN1290WO	Effort to replace Trump on ballot would face tremendous obstacles	"
By Joel Schectman and Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Some prominent Republicans are urging Donald Trump to quit as the party's presidential nominee after video surfaced of him making vulgar comments about women but any attempt to replace Trump on the ballot would face huge legal and logistical hurdles.The real estate magnate has insisted he would never give up the White House race and wrote on Twitter on Sunday that Republicans who are attacking him are ""self-righteous hypocrites.""    With only a month to go before the Nov. 8 election against Democrat Hillary Clinton
column2: it would be a massive stretch to substitute Trump for his running mate Mike Pence or anyone else
column3: Republican strategists and U.S. election experts said.    It is ""virtually impossible to replace somebody in August
column4: let alone October
column5: Republican strategist Karl Rove said on ""Fox News Sunday."" After a video of Trump making vulgar comments about women surfaced Friday
column6: Republicans such as U.S. Senator Mike Lee of Utah and Senator Mark Kirk of Illinois urged Trump to remove himself from the race.The 2005 video showed Trump
column7: then a reality TV star speaking on an open microphone about groping women and trying to seduce a married woman. The video was taped only months after Trump married his third wife
column8: Melania. Making a change at the top of the ticket for one of the two major parties this close to Election Day would be without precedent in the history of modern U.S. presidential elections.In 1972
column9: Democratic presidential candidate George McGovern's running mate
column11: was replaced after it was revealed that the vice presidential hopeful had been hospitalized for depression. Eagleton withdrew from the race in August of that year and was replaced by Sargent Shriver.

column2: Missouri voters faced a last-minute candidate change in the state's U.S. Senate race after the Democratic challenger Mel Carnahan died in a plane crash
column3: a month before the election. Carnahan's name remained on the ballot
column4: however
column5: and the dead man won the election. His widow
column6: Jean Carnahan was appointed to fill the seat.  Republican party rules do not include a mechanism to involuntarily remove from the ticket a presidential candidate who has already been nominated. The party does have procedure
column7: known as Rule 9
column8: that outlines the process for filling a vacancy if a nominee were to die or quit.Republican leaders could try to pressure Trump into resigning by withdrawing financial support for his campaign and withholding logistical help. But as of Sunday
column9: Trump showed no sign of backing down and went on the attack against party figures who have suggested he leave the race.

column1: But if Trump were to decide to quit
column2: the process would involve convening a 160-member committee of the Republican convention to select a new nominee
column3: said Thomas Schwartz
column4: a presidential historian at Vanderbilt University.Experts say such a step would lead to electoral chaos with Republican attorneys fighting state-by-state legal battles to make the last-minute candidate swaps on paper ballots
column5: long after many state deadlines have already passed.Even more daunting
column6: would be how to deal with early or overseas votes already cast. About 411
column7: 000 Americans already have voted in person or through the mail
column8: according to Michael P. McDonald
column9: a Florida State University political science professor who tracks early voting. The figure is sure to grow dramatically over the coming days. Early voting has already begun in six states and this week it will start in eight more.Another problem for Republicans is the risk of legal challenges to the election result. Concern about such challenges could deter some Republicans from voting.

column1: The Republican Party might argue that those ballots already cast for Trump should count toward electoral votes for the replacement candidate
column2: said Matthew Dallek
column3: an expert on presidential politics at George Washington University's Graduate School of Political Management.Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Donna Brazile said the party would likely challenge any effort by Republicans to replace Trump as their candidate on the ballot
column4: adding that it would be ""very confusing"" for voters with early ballots already being cast.""It would be political suicide for Donald Trump to step down right now
column5: she told ABC News. ""I'm sure my legal team is already looking at efforts underway
column6: if there are any efforts underway
column7: she said when asked if Democrats would oppose any effort by Republicans in the states to switch candidates on ballots.Dallek said an effort to substitute a new candidate at this point would lead to ""utter chaos.""""We would be operating in uncharted territory. You would be in this legal netherworld
column8: he said. (Additional reporting by Andy Sullivan and Susan Heavey; Editing by Bill Trott and Alistair Bell)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN12807N	Trump vows to stay in race after lewd remarks surface	"
By Emily Stephenson and Ginger Gibson
(Editors Note: Attention language that may be offensive to some readers in paragraphs 22
column3: 24)By Emily Stephenson and Ginger GibsonNEW YORK/WASHINGTON With his campaign in crisis
column4: U.S. presidential candidate Donald Trump vowed on Saturday to stay in the race despite calls from more than two dozen prominent Republicans for him to drop out following the release of a recording of him making lewd comments about women.Both Trump's wife and his running mate criticized his words
column5: saying they were insulting and indefensible. ""The media and establishment want me out of the race so badly -  I WILL NEVER DROP OUT OF THE RACE
column6: WILL NEVER LET MY SUPPORTERS DOWN!"" Trump wrote on Saturday afternoon on the social media website Twitter.  The video was the latest calamity for Trump
column7: who had hoped to revive his flagging campaign in the face of a recent drop in polls with less than a month until Election Day. Trump is due to appear alongside Democrat Hillary Clinton on Sunday in their second debate in the run-up to the general election. Clinton is not expected to address Trump's video before then.     The 2005 video of Trump talking on an open microphone showed the then-reality TV star speaking about groping women and trying to seduce a married woman. The video was taped only months after Trump married his third wife
column8: Melania.In a statement
column9: Melania Trump called her husband's words ""unacceptable and offensive to me.""""This does not represent the man that I know
column10: she said. ""He has the heart and mind of a leader. I hope people will accept his apology
column12: and focus on the important issues facing our nation and the world.""The backlash over the video was swift and widespread. More than 60 prominent Republican current and former officeholders issued statements condemning Trump's remarks about women
column13: including House Speaker Paul Ryan and John McCain
column14: the party's standard bearer in 2008. More than 20 called for Trump to end his presidential bid. In an unusual move
column15: his vice presidential running mate Mike Pence issued a critical statement of Trump's words
column16: saying on Twitter that he ""cannot defend them.""""As a husband and father
column17: I was offended by the words and actions described by Donald Trump

column1: Pence indicated he would continue to support Trump
column2: despite calls from several Republicans for Trump to step aside and let Pence be the nominee.    There is no precedent for a major party to replace its nominee this late in the campaign and it was unclear if there was an avenue to force him out. Voting has begun in several states
column3: including swing states Virginia and North Carolina.A recorded apology by Trump early on Saturday did not stymie an avalanche of calls from members of his party to quit. Trump huddled on Saturday in Trump Tower with senior advisers
column4: including New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani.Despite previous scheduling
column5: Giuliani will appear on five major Sunday morning news programs
column6: a rare round robin reserved for major news events - replacing Republican Chairman Reince Priebus on CBS's ""Face the Nation"" and campaign manager Kellyanne Conway on ""Fox News Sunday
column7: a last-minute switch. No reason was given for the bump of Conway. A CBS news release said the RNC asked to replace Priebus because Trump's operation wanted ""a campaign person"" to appear on the program.Trump left the building briefly to greet a small crowd of supporters
column8: saying ""100 percent"" he would remain in the race. Before returning to a bank of elevators
column10: ""Tremendous support.""He quickly moved to do damage control in Saturday's video in which he declared himself a changed man and attempted to shift the focus to his opponent Clinton and her husband
column11: former President Bill Clinton. On Twitter
column12: Trump posted critical statements from Juanita Broaddrick
column13: a woman who has accused Bill Clinton of sexually assaulting her.

column1: Anyone who knows me knows these words don't reflect who I am. I said it
column2: I was wrong
column3: and I apologize
column4: Trump said in his video statement
column5: posted on his Facebook page.    COMMENTS CONDEMNED

column1: Trump has struggled to win over women voters
column2: and the video was expected to further feed Democratic criticism about his past behavior toward women. Trump's support has suffered among suburban women and white
column3: college-educated women
column4: groups that Republicans have traditionally won.In the recording that triggered the firestorm
column5: Trump said of one woman
column6: ""I did try and fuck her. She was married."" He went on to discuss his attraction to others.""I just start kissing them
column7: he said. ""And when you're a star they let you do it.""

column1: Grab them by the pussy. You can do anything
column2: Trump said.On Saturday afternoon
column3: CNN published a separate report detailing remarks Trump made over the course of several years while appearing on Howard Stern's radio program.The remarks included discussing the size of his daughter's breasts and that he once had sex with three women at the same time. Trump was asked if he would have sex with a black woman and responded
column4: ""It depends on what your definition of black is."" The remarks were the last straw for some Republicans who have stuck with him through a series of controversial remarks

column7: attacking a judge of Mexican descent
column8: attacking the Gold Star family of a Muslim soldier killed at war and saying Senator John McCain was not a war hero because he had been a prisoner of war.House Speaker Paul Ryan disinvited Trump to a scheduled appearance on Saturday in Wisconsin. Pence declined to speak in his place.The list of Republicans announcing they would not vote for Trump or calling on him to step aside grew on Saturday: Senators Kelly Ayotte

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN1280Z9	Sanders supporters seethe over Clinton's leaked remarks to Wall St.	"
By Luciana Lopez and Jeff Mason
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Supporters of former Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders on Saturday expressed anger and vindication over leaked comments made by Hillary Clinton to banks and big business that appeared to confirm their fears about her support for global trade and tendency to cozy up to Wall Street.Clinton
column2: who needs Sanders' coalition of young and left-leaning voters to propel her to the presidency
column3: pushes for open trade and open borders in one of the speeches
column4: and takes a conciliatory approach to Wall Street
column5: both positions she later backed away from in an effort to capture the popular appeal of Sanders' attacks on trade deals and powerful banks. The excerpts of remarks by the former secretary of state
column6: made in 2013 and 2014 in closed-door meetings where audiences paid to attend
column7: were published online on Friday by WikiLeaks
column8: which sourced them to the email account of John Podesta
column9: Clinton's campaign chairman. Reuters could not independently verify the authenticity of the speech transcripts. Clinton has previously declined to release any such transcripts.""This is a very clear illustration of why there is a fundamental lack of trust from progressives for Hillary Clinton
column11: chair of the People's Lobby in Chicago

column1: Clinton has worked hard to build trust with so-called progressives
column2: adopting several of Sanders' positions after she bested him in the primary race. The U.S. senator from Vermont now supports his former rival in the Nov. 8 general election against Trump.Still
column3: Clinton has struggled to win support from young ""millennials"" who were crucial to Sanders' success
column4: and some Democrats expressed concern that the leaks would discourage those supporters from showing up to vote. ""That is a big concern and this certainly doesn't help
